title: nbdev-hello

title: nbdev-hello
text:
How to use
Fill me in please! Don’t forget code examples:

1+10

11



from nbdev_hello.nbdev_hello import *


psfoo(10)

100



say_hello("Philipp")

'Hello Philipp!'


This is an integral that I know can be solved \[ \int_0^{\infty} \sin(x) \frac{1}{x} dx = 0 \] but I am pretty sure the answer is not zero.
You probably want to substitute variables: \(y = \ln x\) and \(dy/dx = 1/x\), hence \[ \int_0^{\infty} \sin(x) \frac{1}{x} dx =
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \sin(e^y) dy
\] Hmm, not sure that helped a lot… We now have the \(e^y\) term in the \(\sin()\).

1+1

2

  A[Hard edge] --> B(Round edge)
  B --> C{Decision}
  C --> D[Result one]
  C --> E[Result two]

title: Philipps notebook module
text:
source

psfoo

 psfoo (x)


psfoo(17)

289



source


say_hello

 say_hello (to)

Say hello to somebody

say_hello("world")

'Hello world!'



assert psfoo(9)==81
assert psfoo(-2)== 4
assert abs(psfoo(0.1) - 0.01) <1e-8


psfoo(0.1)

0.010000000000000002



assert say_hello("Philipp")=="Hello Philipp!"

floating point arithmetic actually causes some differences here, hence the need to adjust the tests accordingly. For example:

from fastcore.test import *


test_close(psfoo(0.1),0.01)
